Title: Multisensory convergence in auditory cortex, II. Thalamocortical connections of the caudal superior temporal plane
Abstract: "Recent studies of macaque monkey auditory cortex have revealed convergent auditory and somatosensory activity in the caudomedial area (CM) of the belt region. In the present study and its companion (Smiley et al., J. Comp. Neurol. [this issue]), neuroanatomical tracers were injected into CM and adjacent areas of the superior temporal plane to identify sources of auditory and somatosensory input to this region. Other than CM, target areas included: A1, caudolateral belt (CL), retroinsular (Ri), and temporal parietotemporal (Tpt). Cells labeled by injections of these areas were distributed mainly among the ventral (MGv), posterodorsal (MGpd), anterodorsal (MGad), and magnocellular (MGm) divisions of the medial geniculate complex (MGC) and several nuclei with established multisensory features: posterior (Po), suprageniculate (Sg), limitans (Lim), and medial pulvinar (PM). The principal inputs of CM were MGad, MGv, and MGm, with secondary inputs from multisensory nuclei. The main inputs of CL were Po and MGpd, with secondary inputs from MGad, MGm, and multisensory nuclei. A1 was dominated by inputs from MGv and MGad, with light multisensory inputs. The input profile of Tpt closely resembled that of CL, but with reduced MGC inputs. Injections of Ri also involved CM but strongly favored MGm and multisensory nuclei, with secondary inputs from MGC and the inferior division (VPI) of the ventroposterior complex (VP). The results indicate that the thalamic inputs of areas in the caudal superior temporal plane arise mainly from the same nuclei, but in different proportions. Somatosensory inputs may reach CM and CL through MGm or the multisensory nuclei but not VP."

@BrainMaps_Delineation.Citation: "Injections of the target areas in the present study labeled cells mainly in nuclei of the posterior thalamus, especially within and around the MGC. The delineation of thalamic nuclei and their subdivisions was accomplished in adjacent series of sections stained for Nissl, CO, AChE, and in some cases parvalbumin (Fig. 1). Cytoarchitecture, as revealed in sections stained for Nissl, was the principal means of nuclear identification, whereas corresponding density shifts in the expression of CO and AChE reinforced border identification. Patterns of labeled cells were related to these architectonic divisions to derive final reconstructions. The criteria used to delineate subdivisions of the MGC and nearby nuclei in macaque monkeys have been described in detail by our group and others (Jones and Burton,[1976]; Morel et al.,[1993]; Molinari et al.,[1995]; Stepniewska et al., 1997, 2000; Hackett et al.,[1998b]; Gray et al., 1999; Jones,[2003])."

@Methods.Comments: Exact tracer injection methology described in companion paper SHUKLJal07

@Injections.Citation: "In case MAB, injection 1 (FR) was made across all cortical layers within the caudolateral portion of CM near its border with CL and Tpt (Fig. 2)."

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "In the most caudal sections of the thalamus (Nos. 304-328), labeled FR cells (open triangles) were located primarily in MGm, with scattered cells in MGv. In more rostral sections (Nos. 334-364), labeled cells were concentrated in MGad, MGpd, and Z. Labeled cells in MGm tended to be clustered dorsally, where AChE expression was most dense. Nearing the rostral pole of the MGC (sections 358-364), the numbers of labeled cells in MGad decreased and they were clustered near its dorsal border. Here, numerous labeled cells were found in Po and Sg, interspersed among cells labeled by the fast blue injection into Tpt (open squares). Near the rostral pole of the MGC (Nos. 376-388), the VP complex emerged. At this level, cells labeled by the CM injection were clustered in MGad and Po along the dorsolateral edge of VPL and ventral PM. Cells labeled by injections in CM and Tpt tended to overlap in PM, Po, and Sg, but no double-labeled cells were found."

@Injections.Citation: "In case MAM, injection 3 (FR) was made through the cannula into the center of CM (Fig. 3)."

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "Caudally, labeled FR cells were concentrated in MGm, with scattered labeling in MGv, MGpd, and Sg (518-546). As MGad emerged rostrally, labeling in MGm remained high, whereas the numbers of cells increased in MGad and MGv (553-581). Labeling in MGv was distributed fairly broadly, compared with the focalized or clustered labeling that is typical after injections of A1 (e.g., case MY, below; see also Aitkin et al.,[1988]; de la Mothe et al.,[2006b]). As MGad enlarged rostrally, the number of labeled cells increased in MGad as well as in Po and PM (588-630). This pattern persisted through the terminus of the MGC and emergence of VP. Despite spread of tracer along the electrode tract into SII, there were no labeled cells in VP. "

@Injections.Citation: "Tracer injections were made into CM in two cases, CM/Ri in two cases, CM/A1 in one case, CL in two cases, A1 in one case, and Tpt in two cases (Table 1)."
"n case MY, injection 5 (CTB) was centered in rostral CM but also appeared to spread into caudal A1 (Fig. 4)."

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "In case MY, injection 5 (CTB) was centered in rostral CM but also appeared to spread into caudal A1 (Fig. 4). In caudal sections (Nos. 332-302), most of the labeled cells were found in MGm and a few in Sg. Rostral to these sections, a dense locus of labeled cells appeared in the dorsomedial quadrant of MGv (Nos. 297-287), along with projections of comparable density from MGpd and MGad. These cell clusters are illustrated in Figure 5, visible as three distinct patches in a single section (No. 277). The patches are formed by dense clustering of retrogradely labeled somata and their primary dendrites, along with anterogradely labeled terminal arbors. Note that the cellular and fibrodendritic density is higher in MGv than MGpd (Fig. 5C,D). Note also that there was very little evidence of anterograde transport around patches of labeled cells in MGm in this or any other case in which CTB was injected. We also noted reduced anterograde transport to MGm after injections of CM in marmoset monkeys (de la Mothe et al.,[2006b]), suggesting that this may reflect a structural feature of the thalamocortical projection of MGm neurons. Transport to medial MGv persisted rostrally until it began to be displaced by the MGad (Nos. 267-262). The medial location of these labeled cells is consistent with injection of the high-frequency representation in A1 and the known tonotopic organization of the ventral division (Gross et al.,[1974]; Allon et al.,[1981]), although we could not determine whether caudal A1 or rostral CM (or both) contributed. In this case, the concentration of labeled cells was in ventral MGad (Nos. 287-247), which continued to the rostral pole of the MGC. An example of the MGad projection zone is illustrated in Figure 6. Note that the density of labeling is comparable to the patch in MGv (Fig. 5). Moving toward the rostral pole of the MGC, small clusters of labeled cells were found in Po, Sg, Lim, and ventral PM. Because the plane of section was slightly off-coronal, MGad, Po, and VP appeared in some of the same sections (Nos. 252-242). Here, labeled cells were concentrated in MGad and Po along the lateral VPL border."

@Injections.Citation: "In cases MZ (injection 6) and MAG (injection 7), the CTB injections involved CM and Ri. In case MZ, injection 6 was made directly into CM after retraction of the upper bank."

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "In the most caudal sections (Nos. 347-327), labeled cells were concentrated in dorsal MGm, with some in Sg (Fig. 8). Most of these cells were located in the dorsal half of MGm but were rarely among the magnocellular population that gives MGm its name (Fig. 9A-C). Rather, labeled cells tended to be rounded multipolar neurons, intermediate in size (Fig. 9C). In contrast, labeled cells in the Sg were elongated and larger, typically with three primary dendrites (Fig. 9D). Moving rostrally, some labeled cells were scattered in MGv (Nos. 322-312). Although transport to MGpd was sparse in this case, labeled cells were concentrated in MGad from its emergence caudally to its rostral termination near VP (No. 292). Labeling in Po, Sg, Lim, and ventral PM increased with the emergence of MGad, remaining strong up to its rostral termination (No. 292). Examples of labeled cells in Po and PM are illustrated in Figure 10. Groups of cells in Po are divided by bundles of axons that make up the BrSC, compared with uniform cell spacing in PI and PM. The dendritic arbors of labeled cells in these Po clusters tended to be overlapping. In caudal VP (Nos. 292-257), labeled cells were concentrated in Po at the dorsolateral corner of VPL, consistent with other CM injections. In Figure 11, the relationship of MGad, Po, and the VPL fringe is visible, though in a slightly more coronal plane of section compared with Figure 6. The labeled cells were located dorsally in MGad, separated from the main body of VPL by a cell-free septum (Fig. 11C). More rostrally, VPI, portions of VPM, and PL also contained labeled cells, presumably resulting from the involvement of Ri by the injection. "

@Injections.Citation: "In cases MZ (injection 6) and MAG (injection 7), the CTB injections involved CM and Ri."

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "Compared with case MZ (injection 5), this injection involved more of Ri than CM, insofar as some tracer spread into Ri along the electrode track (Fig. 12; see also Smiley et al.,[2007]). The site was responsive to median nerve, click, and tonal stimulation at short latencies. Tuning was somewhat broad, with a best frequency range from 500 to 2,000 Hz. Caudally, the pattern of label was similar to other CM cases in that labeled cells were largely restricted to MGm (Nos. 374-344) and concentrated dorsally. The number of labeled cells in MGpd, Po, Sg, Lim, and ventral PM began to increase rostrally (Nos. 338-302), coincident with the emergence of MGad. Labeling remained strong in Po, Lim, and PM even after the emergence of VP (Nos. 296-272). Although transport to these multisensory nuclei and MGm was relatively strong in this case, the number of cells in MGad was reduced compared with other cases and tended to be concentrated along its dorsal and medial edge. This appears to be due to greater involvement of Ri. Labeled cells also appeared in Po dorsolateral to VPL (Nos. 296-278), overlapping with cells labeled by injections of CM/A1 (FR, open triangles) and CL (fast blue, open squares) in the same case. More rostrally in VP (Nos. 278-254), labeled cells appeared in VPI, LP, and PA. Once again, this likely is due to significant involvement of Ri by the injection. "

@Injections.Citation: "Injections of the caudolateral belt area CL were made directly into cortex after retraction of the upper bank in cases MS (injection 13) and MAG (injection 9)."

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "In case MAG (Fig. 12), injection 9 into CL was made lateral to the CM/Ri injection at the same anteroposterior stereotaxic coordinate (AP +2.8). In caudal sections, FB-labeled cells appeared in dorsal MGm and MGpd (Nos. 346-326). A dense cluster of labeled cells occupied the dorsolateral part of MGpd until the emergence of MGad (Nos. 314-308). Overall, relatively few cells were found in MGad, compared with substantial numbers in Sg, Lim, Po, and PM (Nos. 326-284). Labeled cells in PM were concentrated along its ventral border, as observed after injections in CM/A1 and CM/Ri in this same case, as well as others. In sections containing caudal VP (Nos. 284-272), there was a notable concentration of labeled cells in MGad and Po lateral to VPL. The distribution of labeled cells partially overlapped the distributions of the CM/A1 and CM/Ri injections in this case, especially laterally, but there were no double-labeled cells."

@Injections.Citation: "Direct injections of the temporal parietotemporal area (Tpt) were made in two cases. In case MAB (Fig. 2), injection 10 (FB) was made after retraction of the upper bank. The injection was centered in the portion of Tpt that lies caudal to the belt areas on the superior temporal plane. CL might have been slightly involved by this injection, although the pattern of labeled cells did not resemble the other CL injections in this study."

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "Labeled cells in caudal sections through the MGC were located in MGpd, but few cells were found in any other division of the medial geniculate (Nos. 334-346). Rostrally, most of the labeled cells were located in Sg, Lim, Po, and ventral PM (Nos. 358-388). There were no labeled cells in the lateral VPL fringe region."

@Injections.Citation: "In case MS (Fig. 13), injection 11 (FB) was made directly into Tpt on the lip of the superior temporal gyrus."

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "As in case MAB, labeled cells in the MGC were located mainly in MGpd. Otherwise, cells were concentrated in Po and PM but not in the portion of Po dorsolateral to VPL. Thus, based on these cases, it appears that Tpt receives limited medial geniculate inputs compared with stronger inputs from multisensory nuclei."

publication.title: Multisensory convergence in auditory cortex, II. Thalamocortical connections of the caudal superior temporal plane
publication.abstract: "Recent studies of macaque monkey auditory cortex have revealed convergent auditory and somatosensory activity in the caudomedial area (CM) of the belt region. In the present study and its companion (Smiley et al., J. Comp. Neurol. [this issue]), neuroanatomical tracers were injected into CM and adjacent areas of the superior temporal plane to identify sources of auditory and somatosensory input to this region. Other than CM, target areas included: A1, caudolateral belt (CL), retroinsular (Ri), and temporal parietotemporal (Tpt). Cells labeled by injections of these areas were distributed mainly among the ventral (MGv), posterodorsal (MGpd), anterodorsal (MGad), and magnocellular (MGm) divisions of the medial geniculate complex (MGC) and several nuclei with established multisensory features: posterior (Po), suprageniculate (Sg), limitans (Lim), and medial pulvinar (PM). The principal inputs of CM were MGad, MGv, and MGm, with secondary inputs from multisensory nuclei. The main inputs of CL were Po and MGpd, with secondary inputs from MGad, MGm, and multisensory nuclei. A1 was dominated by inputs from MGv and MGad, with light multisensory inputs. The input profile of Tpt closely resembled that of CL, but with reduced MGC inputs. Injections of Ri also involved CM but strongly favored MGm and multisensory nuclei, with secondary inputs from MGC and the inferior division (VPI) of the ventroposterior complex (VP). The results indicate that the thalamic inputs of areas in the caudal superior temporal plane arise mainly from the same nuclei, but in different proportions. Somatosensory inputs may reach CM and CL through MGm or the multisensory nuclei but not VP."
